bibl.title: Letter from Pedro Nogueira to Philip Showalter Hench, April 22, 1947

div1.p: Nogueira informs Hench that Building No. 1 has been declared a Cuban national monument. He has received Hench's ideas on preserving the building and will keep him informed of Cuban preservation plans.

div1.head: Letter from Pedro Nogueira to Philip Showalter Hench, April 22, 1947
div1.opener:
REPUBLIC OF CUBA
April 22, 1947
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.,
(U. S. A.).-
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of December 6, 1944 addressed to Dr. Jose A. Presno
has been brought to my attention, and I have read with interest your
ideas in regard to Camp Lazear and what you think should be done with
the remains of the little building where the experimental work of the
American Yellow Fever Commission was done. This opportunity was granted
me by Mr. John Moran, and it was his request, as well as the desire of
the Minister of Sanitation, Dr. Jose R. Andreu, that I reply to your
letter and inform you of the important fact that the Cuban Government
has recently declared the building in question a National Monument.

The plans for the preservation of the building may now be
the object of study, and the Minister of Sanitation will no doubt
request from the President of the Republic, the Honorable, Dr. Ramon
Grau San Martin, the necessary funds to carry out the plans definitely
agreed upon, which I shall be most pleased to discuss at the earliest
possible moment in order to terminate this matter in which you have shown
such great interest and which has also deeply interested the Minister
of Sanitation.

I await with pleasure your reply in this regard in order to
inform Doctor Andreu, and beg to remain,

closer.signed:
Dr. Pedro Nogueira,
General Director of Sanitation
